body: Sometimes it is easier to set dynamic configuration options through environment variables. This allows reusing the same Crail configuration file for similar deployments where only non-Crail specific parameters are different (such as the user name, HADOOP/SPARK/CRAIL deployment directories, hostnames).

Hey Radu, can you please open a JIRA (http://crail.incubator.apache.org/community/) for this pull request for discussion. We just do code review on github. 

Also, what happens if a environment variable is not set? Is it possible to do some sort of sanity checks and throw an exception? Because if the variable is not set then probably it is bug (?)

At 3) I mean to extract the options directly from the code (from the CrailConstants-style classes) and update the crail-site.conf.template file in /conf. The options would be ideally commented out and include the default values and comments (if any). It would be much easier for a user to see all configuration options in one place.

There are many ways to do this. I guess we could start by having a look at Hadoop / Spark to see if they do something similar.
Looks good to me. See discussion https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CRAIL-11
This code has been tested with the provided (new) unit tests and a terasort run on 4 machines with the RDMA tier.
Sorry about that. I configured my IDE to remove trailing whitespaces on save.
Added JIRA https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CRAIL-18
This PR is now available as a separate standalone Crail module (https://github.com/zrlio/crail-s3), we should close it.
Fixed all the changes requested by Animesh.
Thanks
Replaced by https://github.com/apache/incubator-crail/pull/30

Just to give some background: If we want our docker images to be publish as the Apache user on Docker Hub the docker build files need to be part of the Apache source repository. (https://hub.docker.com/u/apache/)
Closing this pull request in favor of using the apache parent pom which includes all necessary bits to do releases.
Can we merge this in? What is the holdup

I also think we should just merge and further improve from that point on. We maybe shall relax the target Crail deployment focus in the future from current rack-scale (including cloud etc in the future). 

There is a verb missing in the intro:

> For instance: opening, reading and closing a small file residing in the distributed DRAM tier less than 10 microseconds

better 'it takes' or 'completes in' less than 10us.
Yes, we should merge it, I also think so.
Sure, let's merge.
Lets merge this. Also I think, having something like this would be useful for DaRPC and DiSNI as well?
Why not add the checkstyle plugin to the top level pom?
Let me try again last time I checked it did not work as expected.

Moved plugin to parent pom. Note that I do not yet enforce style check on compilation but you can manually run checkstyle with 'mvn checkstyle:check'. I propose whenever someone changes a file to make two commits one that fixes the style and one for the issue. Otherwise solving all the errors would probably take a few hours...
Also if someone is not happy with the suggestions of the style checker please make a pull request to change the google style derived xml file.
Looks good. Can we just rename google_check.xml to checkstyle.xml?
sure
Renamed file.
Added top-level features back. Changed "Contact" to "Community".

Can you add links to the JIRA issues in the commit message?
Looking at the CRAIL_HOME again I think we should just copy it to /crail instead of /home/crail. What do you think?

Sure, I will add the links.

Ok, it is fine with me to copy to /crail instead of /home/crail. I think it does not matter as much, as long as the path is reasonably easy to use and generic (not include the version number).

I will change it to copy to /crail directly.
Great Thx!
Uploaded the new version with the changes as discussed.
I will create a new pull request with an improved version.
why? We don't want gitignore to be ignored.

Otherwise it will always shows as (this one file lingering around) 
```bash
On branch master
Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)

	.gitignore

nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
```

No, once it is merged it will not show as untracked since only files which are not part of the git repository show up there:
```
$git status
On branch gitignore
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/gitignore'.

nothing to commit, working tree clean
```
This fixes https://jira.apache.org/jira/projects/CRAIL/issues/CRAIL-56 for good
Indeed pretty easy.

Hi Jonas

A minor comment: Since the license directory contains several licenses,
we could rename the directory to licenses. This would also be consistent
with other jars containing a licenses directory. It would also help in case
that someone has a case-insensitive filesystem (LICENSE vs. licenses is fine,
while LICENSE vs. license might not work).

Otherwise looks good.
Makes sense. I will change it accordingly.
Thanks!
Updated commit to include JIRA.
OK, I will close this pull request
Thanks!

One way to have more flexibility and be semantically consistent,
would be to introduce three static functions to create an
empty configuration, create a configuration from the default
configuration file and create a configuration from the file given
as parameter and set the current public constructor to private.

The code would be something like this:

```
private CrailConfiguration() {
  ...
}

public static CrailConfiguration createEmptyConfiguration() {
  ...
}
public static CrailConfiguration createConfigurationFromFile() {
  ...
}
public static CrailConfiguration createConfigurationFromFile(String path) {
  ...
}
```

The function `createEmptyConfiguration` instantiates an empty configuration.
The user can set properties by calling `public void set(String key, String value)`
and `public void setInt(String key, int level)`, two already existing functions.

`createConfigurationFromFile` instantiates `CrailConfiguration` and
loads the default configuration file. This would be the exact same
behaviour as the current default public constructior `CrailConfiguration()`.

`createConfigurationFromFile(String path)` would do the same as the above
function, but read the configuration from the explicitely given full
path to the configuration file, instead of loading the default
configuration file.

This implies a change to the applications. Applications cannot
call `new CrailConfiguration()` anymore (constructor is private),
but need to be changed to call `createConfigurationFromFile()`,
which has the exact same semantic as the currently public
`CrailConfiguration()` constructor.

How does that sounds?
Looks good!

Hi all

I implemented the functions as proposed above and updated the PR. I tested the following:
- Regular Crail based on TCP works (namenode, datanode, Crail client)
- Containerized Crail on Kubernetes works (namenode, datanode, NVMf datanode, client)
- Serverless function on OpenWhisk can access containerized Crail service
- fsck works
- iobench (tested with -t read and -t write) works
- binary SNAPSHOT (.tar.gz) produced by Maven works

Could you please have a look at the updated commit?
Thanks

Hi! thank you for your contribution. I'm not familiar with the project but this looks interesting.

one question: is there a reason for these .so files? generally in Apache projects we must avoid committing binary files into source repo.

Hi,

Thanks a ton for your support.
As i am building the docker image from crail binary which is included
within .These .so files are a part of crail binary from which the docker
image is getting built which is in turn used in the kubernetes artifacts
supplied by me .These kubernetes artifacts will help in scalable deployment
of Crail both public cloud,on premise as well as hybrid cloud which is
absent in present version of Crail.

Please feel free to contact me in case further queries or clarifications

Thanks & Regards,
Kaustav

Hi Kaustav

It is not exactly true that Crail does not have this support. While support for Kubernetes is not yet checked into Apache Crail, we have support for Kubernetes in Pocket, which is a joint project between our team and Stanford: https://github.com/stanford-mast/pocket. Also, I am working on a more native integeration with Kubernetes, which does not require special privilege flags, nor host networking and does not need binary files to be checked in: https://github.com/asqasq/serverless

It seems to me that you copied the files from one of these repositories, slightly changed them and created the PR based on those files.

Hi ,

I saw pocket and found that it is using host networking.Yes some of the
concept is taken from there but i have created the services for master and
slave as well as removed the concept of host networking and tested it with
flannel networks.
On top of that there are configuration changes in the docker build as well
for adapting with pod networking.

Thanks & Regards
Kaustav

Hi Kaustav

Actually I do understand the flow.

This PR cannot be merged for several reasons:
1. In my opinion it is not the right way to just copy files from other people and claim that
   they are youres (even more, you copied our files from our repositories)
2. The Pocket files do not work with the latest Crail version. Pocket was a research project
    based on a older and especially a modified version of Crail.
3. It seems to me that you don't understand what you are doing
4. I doubt that you tested it, especially after your last change. Deleting few files
    could potentially mean that something does not work anymore (I doubt that it worked before).
5. We cannot reference docker images from a non-trusted source in the yaml files.

Therefore, we cannot merge this PR.

Hi Adrian,

Thanks for your feedback .
I will close this PR.

Thanks
Kaustav
